linkTarget.anchoringText: The Petrocedeño field is an onshore extra heavy oil field (8-10 ˚ API) located in the Orinoco Oil belt, Venezuela (Fig. 1) and operated by PDVSA (60%), with the partners TOTAL (30%) and STATOIL (10%). Since 2000 it has been producing crude oil by means of natural depletion through horizontal wells from the shallow reservoirs (230-475 m) made up of unconsolidated sands of the Early to Middle Miocene Oficina Formation. The field covers an area of 399 km2 and over the years a high density of data has been acquired, including more than 1000 wells (deviated or vertical stratigraphic wells and horizontal producer wells), over 6000 ft of core and 3D seismic data.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Location map of Venezuela with the Orinoco heavy-oil belt and the Petrocedeño Field (Martinius et al., 2012)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Location map of Venezuela with the Orinoco heavy-oil belt and the Petrocedeño Field (Martinius et al., 2012)

linkTarget.bib:
Martinius et al., 2012
Allard W. Martinius , Jan Hegner , Inge Kaas , Celia Bejarano , Xavier Mathieu , and Rune Mjøs , 2012. Sedimentology and depositional model for the Early Miocene Oficina Formation in the Petrodecedeño Field (Orinoco heavy-oil belt, Venezuela). Marine and Petroleum Geology
35 (2012): 354 380 .

linkTarget.anchoringText: The productive reservoirs of the Petrocedeño field are of the lower Oficina formation. These Early Miocene sediments are part of a wedge deposited onto Cretaceous or crystalline basement of the eastern Venezuelan fore deep basin (Fig. 2, Martinius et al., 2013). They were deposited in fluvial to tide-dominated deltaic environments filling in the basin. The lower Oficina formation has an operational subdivision of a lower fluvial and an upper transitional/deltaic part.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: A schematic cross section of the fore deep basin and the infill of the Oficina formation. The stratigraphic column and the approximate location of the Petrocedeño field is marked by the red box (Martinius et al., 2012 as reproduced in Vega and Rojas, 1987)

formatted-caption.caption-text: A schematic cross section of the fore deep basin and the infill of the Oficina formation. The stratigraphic column and the approximate location of the Petrocedeño field is marked by the red box (Martinius et al., 2012 as reproduced in Vega and Rojas, 1987)

linkTarget.bib:

35 (2012): 354 380 .

Vega and Rojas, 1987
A. Vega and I. Rojas
1987. Exploration and evaluation of the Zuata area, Orinoco oil belt, Venezuela. Journal of Petroleum Geology , v. 10: p. 163 176 .

linkTarget.anchoringText: The lower Oficina formation has an operational subdivision of a lower fluvial and an upper transitional/deltaic part. This was further subdivided into six units, F-D for the fluvial part and C-A for the superior transitional/deltaic part (Fig. 3, Martinius et al., 2013). The reservoir model described in this paper contains the deltaic B unit which consists of meandering channel belts with point bar and crevasse splay deposits with as non-reservoir facies the floodplain, accretion surfaces/mud drapes and clay plug deposits (Fig. 4 and Fig. 5).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Stratigraphic illustration of the productive reservoirs of the Petrocedeño field with a type well logs (Martinius et al., 2012)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Stratigraphic illustration of the productive reservoirs of the Petrocedeño field with a type well logs (Martinius et al., 2012)

35 (2012): 354 380 .

linkTarget.anchoringText: The lower Oficina formation has an operational subdivision of a lower fluvial and an upper transitional/deltaic part. This was further subdivided into six units, F-D for the fluvial part and C-A for the superior transitional/deltaic part (Fig. 3, Martinius et al., 2013). The reservoir model described in this paper contains the deltaic B unit which consists of meandering channel belts with point bar and crevasse splay deposits with as non-reservoir facies the floodplain, accretion surfaces/mud drapes and clay plug deposits (Fig. 4 and Fig. 5).

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Conceptual model of a meandering fluvial system showing (a) main channel belt, (b) vertical communication between reservoir units, (c) point bar deposits (d) clay plug deposit and (e) lateral facies change within channel belt (modified after Gouw, 2007 as reproduced in Weerts, 1996)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The lower Oficina formation has an operational subdivision of a lower fluvial and an upper transitional/deltaic part. This was further subdivided into six units, F-D for the fluvial part and C-A for the superior transitional/deltaic part (Fig. 3, Martinius et al., 2013). The reservoir model described in this paper contains the deltaic B unit which consists of meandering channel belts with point bar and crevasse splay deposits with as non-reservoir facies the floodplain, accretion surfaces/mud drapes and clay plug deposits (Fig. 4 and Fig. 5).

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Schematic diagram of point bar deposits showing (a) associated accretion surfaces/mud drapes, (b) vertical evolution of facies and (c) clay plug deposits

formatted-caption.caption-text: Schematic diagram of point bar deposits showing (a) associated accretion surfaces/mud drapes, (b) vertical evolution of facies and (c) clay plug deposits

linkTarget.anchoringText: The first step of the workflow was to create the framework deterministically. Paleogeographic maps focusing on representing the channel belt locations and organization per reservoir unit were made using the sedimentological understanding and interpretation of the stratigraphic wells. These were consequently fine tuned using net-sand maps and information from the horizontal wells (Fig. 6A). The maps for the successive interval are then used to define a 3D parameter in the geocelular model representing the different depositional environments (Fig. 7).

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: (A) Paleogeographic map contour superposing net-sand map with horizontal wells. (B) The resulting deposition environment model

formatted-caption.caption-text: (A) Paleogeographic map contour superposing net-sand map with horizontal wells. (B) The resulting deposition environment model

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Paleogeographic map contour superposing net-sand map with horizontal wells.
The resulting deposition environment model

linkTarget.anchoringText: The first step of the workflow was to create the framework deterministically. Paleogeographic maps focusing on representing the channel belt locations and organization per reservoir unit were made using the sedimentological understanding and interpretation of the stratigraphic wells. These were consequently fine tuned using net-sand maps and information from the horizontal wells (Fig. 6A). The maps for the successive interval are then used to define a 3D parameter in the geocelular model representing the different depositional environments (Fig. 7).

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: The reservoir channel belt defined per reservoir unit of the B unit in the geocelular model

formatted-caption.caption-text: The reservoir channel belt defined per reservoir unit of the B unit in the geocelular model

linkTarget.anchoringText: The 2nd steps of the workflow, was to model the facies associations by means of SIS within the defined depositional environment 3D model (Fig. 8). The main input parameters were the wells with facies association logs, variogram dimensions, and most importantly a probability cube that allowed the representation of vertical and lateral geological trends within each interval.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: (A) The depositional geomodel. (B) The facies association model propagated using SIS within the depositional model framework

formatted-caption.caption-text: (A) The depositional geomodel. (B) The facies association model propagated using SIS within the depositional model framework

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: The depositional geomodel.
The facies association model propagated using SIS within the depositional model framework

linkTarget.anchoringText: In order to control the vertical and lateral distribution of the point bar (sand) and mudstone (shale) facies as observed in the wells, a probability cube was created and used as input in the SIS. The first step in creating this probability cube was to implement the vertical facies evolution per reservoir unit, observed at the stratigraphic wells. A vertical proportion curve (VPC) based on the stratigraphic wells (Fig. 9A) were constructed per unit using facies proportion statistics per 5 ft layer. After normalization (Fig. 9B) they were converted into 3D probability cubes, one for shale and one for sand (Fig. 9C).

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: (A) VPC from the stratigraphic wells for a reservoir zone. (B) Corresponding probability curve for Mudstone. (C) Cross section of the 3D probability cube showing the vertical probabilities for Mudstone in the corresponding reservoir zone

formatted-caption.caption-text: (A) VPC from the stratigraphic wells for a reservoir zone. (B) Corresponding probability curve for Mudstone. (C) Cross section of the 3D probability cube showing the vertical probabilities for Mudstone in the corresponding reservoir zone

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: VPC from the stratigraphic wells for a reservoir zone.
Corresponding probability curve for Mudstone.
Cross section of the 3D probability cube showing the vertical probabilities for Mudstone in the corresponding reservoir zone

linkTarget.anchoringText: The second input data included in the probability cube was the potential vertical communication between different reservoir units. At the interface between each reservoir unit, shale thickness maps (Fig. 10A) were created, a result of correlation and kriging of shale thickness data between the stratigraphic wells. These maps provided the information needed, as areas with thin or absent shale barrier are areas of potential communication, whereas areas of thick shale obviously prevent vertical flow.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: (A) A shale barrier thickness map corresponding to a reservoir zone interface. (B) Consequent lateral shale probability incorporated in the probability cube

formatted-caption.caption-text: (A) A shale barrier thickness map corresponding to a reservoir zone interface. (B) Consequent lateral shale probability incorporated in the probability cube

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: A shale barrier thickness map corresponding to a reservoir zone interface.
Consequent lateral shale probability incorporated in the probability cube

linkTarget.anchoringText: The resulting probability cube (Fig. 11A) guided the SIS simulation, resulting in a facies association parameter (Fig. 11B) respecting both the vertical evolution and the potential area of inter-unit commu-nication: more sandy facies are present in area of potential vertical communication, and shally facies in area where barrier were identified.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: (A) Shale probability cube. (B) Associated facies model

formatted-caption.caption-text: (A) Shale probability cube. (B) Associated facies model

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Shale probability cube.
Associated facies model

linkTarget.anchoringText: In the 3rd step of the workflow, the facies were modeled using SIS into the existing facies association model (Fig. 12). As the facies association model already included strong lateral and vertical trends, the facies were modeled without additional trend inputs. The facies are computed at the wells using a cut-off. Concerning the variogram settings, the same approach was used as for the modeling of the facies associations: dimension and sinuosity being similar. This enabled the facies to be distributed following the main channel geometries defined by the facies association stage (Fig. 12B).

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: (A) A layer of the facies association model. (B) Corresponding facies model within which the petrophysical propierties will be propagated

formatted-caption.caption-text: (A) A layer of the facies association model. (B) Corresponding facies model within which the petrophysical propierties will be propagated

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: A layer of the facies association model.
Corresponding facies model within which the petrophysical propierties will be propagated

linkTarget.anchoringText: Analysis of the facies association modelled, showed that the vertical facies evolution was successfully implemented and the desired petrophysical signature achieved. This can be seen by comparing the VPC from well observations (Fig. 13A), the VPC from the model (Fig. 13B) with the vertical evolution shown by the average volume of wet clay per layer from model (Fig. 13C).

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: (A) Facies association VPC from a reservoir zone based on logs from stratigraphic wells. (B) Facies association VPC from the corresponding reservoir unit based on the 3D facies association parameter. (C) Average modeled volume wet clay per layer from the same reservoir unit showing the effect of the implemented vertical facies evolution to the petrophysical model

formatted-caption.caption-text: (A) Facies association VPC from a reservoir zone based on logs from stratigraphic wells. (B) Facies association VPC from the corresponding reservoir unit based on the 3D facies association parameter. (C) Average modeled volume wet clay per layer from the same reservoir unit showing the effect of the implemented vertical facies evolution to the petrophysical model

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Facies association VPC from a reservoir zone based on logs from stratigraphic wells.
Facies association VPC from the corresponding reservoir unit based on the 3D facies association parameter.
Average modeled volume wet clay per layer from the same reservoir unit showing the effect of the implemented vertical facies evolution to the petrophysical model

linkTarget.anchoringText: The implementations of the shale barrier maps in the same phase can be seen by volume of wet clay average maps of the concerning unit interfaces (Fig. 14B) but are at the same time very much dependent on the shale proportion in the corresponding layers. Impact on the dynamic simulation has yet to be evaluated.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: (A) A shale barrier thickness map corresponding to a reservoir unit interface. (B) Volume wet clay average map of the interval to which the barrier thickness map (A) was applied to

formatted-caption.caption-text: (A) A shale barrier thickness map corresponding to a reservoir unit interface. (B) Volume wet clay average map of the interval to which the barrier thickness map (A) was applied to

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: A shale barrier thickness map corresponding to a reservoir unit interface.
Volume wet clay average map of the interval to which the barrier thickness map (A) was applied to

linkTarget.anchoringText: Sand distribution can be independently validated by comparing the net-sand maps per reservoir units from the model (Fig. 15B) with the operational net-sand maps (Fig. 15A). This shows that the main trends are well represented in the model with the expected uncertainty.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: (A) Operational net sand map of a reservoir unit. (B) Net sand map from the static model of the same reservoir unit

formatted-caption.caption-text: (A) Operational net sand map of a reservoir unit. (B) Net sand map from the static model of the same reservoir unit

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Operational net sand map of a reservoir unit.
Net sand map from the static model of the same reservoir unit

linkTarget.anchoringText: The sinuous patterns of the facies model gave the expected result in the petrophysical model. In figure 16 the facies model (Fig. 16A) is compared to the permeability model (Fig. 16A). The high permeability streaks coincide with the good sand locations and follow the same trend as the facies model (Fig. 16). The concept that higher quality sands are deposited along the axis potentially resulting in preferential flow have shown to be implemented.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: (A) A layer of the facies model. (B) The same layer of the permeability model showing the same trend and the high permeability streaks where good sands are propagated in the facies model (A)

formatted-caption.caption-text: (A) A layer of the facies model. (B) The same layer of the permeability model showing the same trend and the high permeability streaks where good sands are propagated in the facies model (A)

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: A layer of the facies model.
The same layer of the permeability model showing the same trend and the high permeability streaks where good sands are propagated in the facies model (A)
